text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 11.51.2, Large Business and International Communications, LB&I Intranet Publishing Standards.
MATERIAL CHANGES

IRM 11.51.2.1 is now Program Scope and Objectives. This subsection details internal control information about LB&I intranet publishing standards. Moved content from IRM 11.51.2.3, LB&I Web Publishing Responsibilities, to this subsection.
Added paragraph about plain language to IRM 11.51.2.4, Writing for the Intranet.
Added 10 pt. to the standard font criteria in IRM 11.51.2.8.3, Standard Fonts.
Added clariﬁcation to IRM 11.51.2.8.6, Page Length.
Rewrote IRM 11.51.2.8.7, Page Titles, considering the move to the IRS Source platform.
reference to IRS Publishing Services in IRM 11.51.2.8.8.2, Adobe PDF.
Added note about highlighted text to IRM 11.51.2.8.5, Text Elements.
This IRM supersedes IRM 11.51.2 dated June 10, 2016.
AUDIENCE
Table of Contents
LB&I Intranet Publishing Standards

) Purpose: The LB&I Web Team has developed a set of Publishing and Standards to ensure a consistent look and feel throughout the LB&I Source. and These standards must be adhered to, to provide a user experience that tates the primary goal of information availability, as well as the IRS Source policy of presenting information in a content-based manner.. (
) Audience: LB&I personnel trained and permissioned as content owners, content managers and subject matter experts (SMEs) on the LB&I Source. (
) Policy Owner: The LB&I Director of Resource Solutions is the executive owner for this IRM section. (
) Program Owner: The LB&I Director of Communications & Liaison is the program owner for this IRM section. (

) Primary Stakeholders: The stakeholders for the program are the users of LB&I Source. This population consists of all LB&I employees, in addition to IRS employees that use content on the LB&I Source. (
) Program Goals: The goal of the program is to ensure consistency of throughout the site, consistency of content presentation with the IRS vision, and in compliance with IRM
, Content Policies and Standards Intranet Sites. (

) IRS Source vs. LB&I Intranet: The LB&I intranet migrated to the IRS platform as part of the Servicewide vision of moving all intranet content to Source as the replacement of the IRWeb. LB&I was the ﬁrst major business unit to migrate, due to the Windows Server
end-of-life. (

) Content Dispersal: The IRS vision for intranet content, requires splitting of content that was formerly housed in singular intranet sites. This vision is lated by IRS C&L; and consists of content in one of three platforms: • IRS Source (and business unit sub-sites) – information on operations, organization, and news items • Servicewide Knowledge Library – information on “how to do your for knowledge retention and sharing • Collaborative Shar
oint sites – restricted permission sites, for documents and information, and small-team collaborative efforts (
) Authority for intra-site consistency is derived from IRM
, Intranet and Servers Must Be Registered. (

) The LB&I Web Team is responsible for: • Providing overall standards for the LB&I Source • Managing the global navigation and content regions • Managing the overall LB&I Source design and governance • Providing content managers the tools and subject matter technical support necessary to perform their duties • Managing root-level content and content-based landing pages • Managing the Headquarters level organization-based pages • Managing LB&I Source news items (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Audience: LB&I personnel trained and permissioned as content owners, content managers and subject matter experts (SMEs) on the LB&I

IRS Source (and business unit sub-sites) – information on day-to-day operations, organization, and news items Servicewide Knowledge Library – information on “how to do your job”, for knowledge retention and sharing Collaborative Shar
oint sites – restricted permission sites, for documents and information, and small-team collaborative efforts
Authority for intra-site consistency is derived from IRM 11.1.4.4, Intranet Sites and Servers Must Be Registered.

Large Business and International • Instructing the LB&I Web Publishing Course (ELMS #
) or lent • Being the focal point of contact for web technology in LB&I • Being the focal point of contact for web server applications in LB&I (
) Content managers are responsible for: • Successfully completing the LB&I Web Publishing Course (ELMS #

) and any required prerequisites or post-requisites. • Completing any refresher or follow-up training related to the Web Pub- lishing Course • Performing all list maintenance and content reviews necessary • Conducting quarterly review of list permissions to ensure currency and accuracy of its members • Updating and maintaining list metadata for which they are assigned • Providing technical support to content SMEs regarding web-based mation and presentation • Directing inquiries related to technical content to the appropriate channels • Adhering to the LB&I Web Publishing and Intranet Standards • Adhering to the IRS Intranet standards (

) Content owners are responsible for: • Identifying candidates for the role of content manager and SME, and providing those candidates with the time and resources necessary to complete the required training • Ensuring there is an established review and approval process for all content to be published to the Source • Ensuring that the review process includes Section

compliance checks, E-FOIA and SBREFA (Small Business Regulatory Fairness Act) compliance, and any other applicable regulations • Ensuring each LB&I Source list under their purview is still valid and contains only current information • Ensuring that content managers and SMEs are properly trained and equipped to perform their duties • Ensuring that content managers and SMEs are provided adequate and support to manage their assigned content (

) SMEs are responsible for: • Ensuring the content on their pages is current and up-to-date • Coordinating with their content managers regarding any problems or metadata changes they may need • Ensuring that content posted on their pages is Section

compliant • Coordinating release of information on IRS.gov that is subject to or SBREFA (Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act) • Removing any content that is obsolete or out-of-date • Correct spelling and grammar of content submitted for publishing • Identifying when/if they expect to be unable to serve in the SME capacity • Ensuring the established review and approval process is followed submitting updates

Intranet Publishing Standards 11.51.2
Commonly used terms and acronyms are deﬁned below.

Term Deﬁnition Aircard A device that allows a broadband internet con- nection, typically via USB interface, without a wired (RJ-45 ethernet) or wireless (802.11 protocol). Acronyms Acronym Deﬁnition ASP Active Server Pages CSS Cascading Style Sheets E-FOIA Electronic Freedom of Information Act ERAP Employee Remote Access Project HTML HyperText Markup Language LAN Local Area Network PDF Portable Document Format SBREFA Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act SME Subject Matter Expert WCAG Web Content Accessibility Guidelines
The W3Schools website is a good resource for learning HTML, CSS, Javascript and other web-related topics. See
Large Business and International (
) Proprietary Computer Code - Per IRM

, Proprietary Computer Must Be Approved Before Use, the use of proprietary computer code (to include open source code) is restricted to only those approved by IRS IT terprise Architecture. LB&I has obtained approval for the use of the JQuery and Bootstrap javascript libraries. No other proprietary computer code is to used on the LB&I intranet, without written authorization from the LB&I Webmaster. (

) Custom-built Web Code - Custom-built javascript code can be used on the LB&I intranet, after receiving approval from the LB&I Webmaster in writing. This includes any custom javascript or CAML script, as they can the security of the Shar
oint environment. Custom code must be the LB&I Web Team for review and approval prior to implementation. (

) Included HTML Content – Methods of including external HTML, and other based code, must be approved by the LB&I Webmaster and the IRS Cybersecurity office. Virtual inclusion of external content compromises the security structure of the IRS Source and Shar

oint servers. An error in a code loop could result in a perpetual burden on the web servers, and could cause them to crash, resulting in a denial of service for the entire IRS hosted on the physical server. (

) This sub-section provides the general guidelines and restrictions for content published to the LB&I Source. These guidelines and restrictions ensure ance with accessibility laws, privacy laws, as well as with the Servicewide standards. (

) Content on the LB&I Source will be maintained as long as it remains accurate, and applicable. Content that no longer serves a business purpose will be removed to ensure availability of storage space, as well as to confusion for users. (

) Content will be archived according to standard practice, and will not be tained on the web for “historical” purposes. Content that is required to be maintained for “historical” or other “archiving” purposes should be using appropriate record retention methods by the content owner. (

) Content must also properly belong on the LB&I Source, or have an from the LB&I webmaster to be temporarily housed in the LB&I Source. Content with a temporary exception will be maintained for a period of one after which time, it must receive another exception to remain on the LB&I Source. Other proper platforms for content are the Servicewide Knowledge Management Library, and Shar
oint collaborative sites. (
) If content properly belongs in the Source platform, but has a servicewide audience, the author/owner will coordinate with the LB&I Web Team to have placed on the IRS Source. (
) If the content properly belongs in the Servicewide Virtual Library or a collab- orative Shar
oint site, the author/owner will coordinate with the HCO SKM team or the LB&I Shar
oint Project Office to have it placed in the platform.
Large Business and International Communications

cause them to crash, resulting in a denial of service for the entire IRS Source hosted on the physical server. This sub-section provides the general guidelines and restrictions for content published to the LB&I Source. These guidelines and restrictions ensure ance with accessibility laws, privacy laws, as well as with the Servicewide standards. Content on the LB&I Source will be maintained as long as it remains current, accurate, and applicable. Content that no longer serves a business purpose will be removed to ensure availability of storage space, as well as to confusion for users. Content will be archived according to standard practice, and will not be main- tained on the web for “historical” purposes. Content that is required to be maintained for “historical” or other “archiving” purposes should be maintained using appropriate record retention methods by the content owner. Content must also properly belong on the LB&I Source, or have an exception from the LB&I webmaster to be temporarily housed in the LB&I Source. Content with a temporary exception will be maintained for a period of one after which time, it must receive another exception to remain on the LB&I Source. Other proper platforms for content are the Servicewide Knowledge Management Library, and Shar

oint collaborative sites. If content properly belongs in the Source platform, but has a servicewide audience, the author/owner will coordinate with the LB&I Web Team to have placed on the IRS Source. If the content properly belongs in the Servicewide Virtual Library or a collab- orative Shar
oint site, the author/owner will coordinate with the HCO SKM team or the LB&I Shar
oint Project Office to have it placed in the platform.

Content must also properly belong on the LB&I Source, or have an exception from the LB&I webmaster to be temporarily housed in the LB&I Source. Content with a temporary exception will be maintained for a period of one year, after which time, it must receive another exception to remain on the LB&I Source. Other proper platforms for content are the Servicewide Knowledge Management Library, and SharePoint collaborative sites.
U.S.C.
d – commonly referred to as “Section

of the Rehabilitation requires all Federal agencies to make their electronic and information ogy accessible to people with disabilities. To comply with this requirement, all visual content must provide a text-only format, available to screen reader nology. Additionally, the following considerations are to be followed: • Images, pictures, and diagrams should provide alternative text where appropriate • Images that only serve a visual function, and could inhibit the of a webpage if “ﬁller” alternative text is provided, should be given a NULL alt text value (alt=””) • Red text should be avoided, except for the common practice of input validation • Underlined text should never be used, as it commonly denotes text • Italicized text should only be used for quoted material • Emphasis may be provided using boldface text (<strong> HTML tag), but it should be used sparingly, and in a manner that does not detract from the readability of the page (

) Files uploaded, and made available for users to download via hyperlink, be thoroughly checked for accessibility. While all parties involved are respon- sible for the accessibility of documents published to the web, Content providers/contributors/authors retain the primary responsibility for correcting any accessibility shortfalls. The built-in accessibility tools in the Microsoft Suite and Adobe Acrobat provide adequate functionality for ensuring Section

compliance. Documents may be submitted to the IRS Alternative Media Center for review prior to publishing to the intranet, or alternatively, the LB&I Web Team can assist with some accessibility concerns. (

) In general, the LB&I intranet must be presented in an accessible format. Ac- cessibility of web content is not a “compliant” or “non-compliant” issue, but rather a sliding scale, by which content can have varying degrees of compli- ance. The foremost goal is to provide a web experience to all users, which is as nearly identical as practical. Resources for accessibility include: • The IRS Alternative Media Center (AMC) Office • The IRS Information Resources Accessibility Program (IRAP) Office • IRS Web Services • Section
regulations • WCAG
Guidelines • ELMS courses
and

) Content published on the intranet must properly reﬂect the professional of the Internal Revenue Service and the Large Business & International Division. No content should be published that reﬂects poorly upon LB&I or IRS. (

) All content published to the LB&I intranet must have a valid business and serve the overall goals of LB&I. Content should help users take a action, learn or reinforce a skill, or ﬁnd content related to their official duties.

Images, pictures, and diagrams should provide alternative text where appropriate Images that only serve a visual function, and could inhibit the of a webpage if “ﬁller” alternative text is provided, should be given a NULL alt text value (alt=””) Red text should be avoided, except for the common practice of input validation Underlined text should never be used, as it commonly denotes text Italicized text should only be used for quoted material Emphasis may be provided using boldface text (<strong> HTML tag), but it should be used sparingly, and in a manner that does not detract from the readability of the page

Files uploaded, and made available for users to download via hyperlink, should be thoroughly checked for accessibility. While all parties involved are respon- sible for the accessibility of documents published to the web, Content providers/contributors/authors retain the primary responsibility for correcting any accessibility shortfalls. The built-in accessibility tools in the Microsoft Office Suite and Adobe Acrobat provide adequate functionality for ensuring Section

compliance. Documents may be submitted to the IRS Alternative Media Center for review prior to publishing to the intranet, or alternatively, the LB&I Web Team can assist with some accessibility concerns.

regulations WCAG
Guidelines ELMS courses
and

All content published to the LB&I intranet must have a valid business purpose, and serve the overall goals of LB&I. Content should help users take a required action, learn or reinforce a skill, or ﬁnd content related to their official duties.
Large Business and International (

) The IRS’s policy on limited personal use extends not only to users of the intranet, but also to Content Publishers regarding content publishing. LB&I intranet pages must not link to content that is inappropriate or prohibited by IRS limited personal use policy. (

) Content should not be duplicated on the LB&I intranet. This means that if content is available elsewhere on the IRS network, content managers should link to the relevant content. Additionally, if content is published on the public- facing internet (IRS.gov), LB&I intranet pages should link to that content, than generate duplicate information. These rules are in addition to E-FOIA SBREFA considerations. (

) Sensitive But Unclassiﬁed (SBU) information should never be published to LB&I intranet. SBU content includes (but is not limited to) tax and personnel (privacy) information. For example; publishing speciﬁc tax cases even if removing the taxpayer identifying information is inappropriate and unaccept- able. (

) If Official Use Only (OUO) information is published on the LB&I intranet it be clearly identiﬁable as OUO information by indicating the # sign where the OUO information is located, along with other identifying information at the top of the webpage, to indicate that it contains OUO information. HTML coding should be used to remove this information from the printable webpage so that it cannot be printed and inadvertently provided to outside entities. To set content to be non-printable, add the class attribute “no print” to the container element. (

) Source and Attribution is an acceptable manner of publishing third-party mation. However, care must be used to ensure that the source of the information is identiﬁed and the information is not embellished with from the tax or personnel record. Example: You can publish the success of an indictment or conviction using wording like: In the Newark Star Ledger dated February
it
Large Business and International Communications
You can publish the success of an indictment or conviction using wording like: In the Newark Star Ledger dated February
it was reported that... “the United States Attorney received an indictment against John Q. Public for tax evasion as the result of his involvement in an abusive tax scheme. ”

The important thing to remember is to include the source and attribute the in- formation to the source, so as not to accidentally give the impression that the IRS or LB&I are the source. When possible, link to the original source. (
) Every page on the LB&I intranet should have a clear purpose and audience. If appropriate, consider a brief introductory sentence or paragraph to describe the purpose of the page. (

) The excessive use of images and graphics has a negative impact on website readability and performance (speed of page loading). Use images sparingly and only when the image adds value to the content it accompanies or supports a business goal. Further information regarding accessibility standards can be found in IRM
, Accessibility of Web Content. Further information regarding graphics can be found in IRM
, Image and Graphic Speci- ﬁcations.

The important thing to remember is to include the source and attribute the in- formation to the source, so as not to accidentally give the impression that the IRS or LB&I are the source. When possible, link to the original source.

The excessive use of images and graphics has a negative impact on website readability and performance (speed of page loading). Use images sparingly and only when the image adds value to the content it accompanies or supports a business goal. Further information regarding accessibility standards can be found in IRM
, Accessibility of Web Content. Further information regarding graphics can be found in IRM
, Image and Graphic Speci- ﬁcations.
Intranet Publishing Standards 11.51.2

) All webpages must be checked for spelling and grammatical errors as well ensuring that links are valid, before they are published. Do not solely rely the software’s “Spell Check” function. Proofread all content for readability correct errors that may have been missed by the spell checker. (
) Writing for the intranet is very different from writing for a hardcopy print medium. Studies have shown that reading from computer screens is
for the Intranet percent slower and creates more eyestrain than reading from hardcopy. (

) Plain Language writing should be used to convey information succinctly clearly to readers. The Servicewide training course “Writing for the Web” is good resource for content developers, and “Write This Way” is a good resource for general grammar and English language conventions. (

) It is important to identify your target audience and understand their needs. Remember LB&I employees, managers, and executives are very busy and Your Intended need to access speciﬁc information on your webpages quickly and • Be an advocate for your audience. What do they want to know? do you need to tell them? Is it all there? Did you anticipate their questions? Did you lead them to pertinent related materials? • Understand your audience’s connectivity limitations. Many users are accessing your webpages through ERAP with slow connection This fact should always be a big part of your decision of what to put your webpages. • Use words and terminology appropriate to your intended audience. What words would your audience use? • Clearly explain all new or non-standard terms. When you introduce or unfamiliar acronyms, use the acronym and then, in parentheses, out the name or expression. Do not assume that the audience is with the term from another page of content. (

) Clearly state the purpose of the page in the ﬁrst paragraph. Introduce your topic at the start of your page and progress logically to the conclusion. Ambiguity Following this approach will help users identify if they are on the correct It can also help the search engine ﬁnd the correct page, based upon the content.

Be an advocate for your audience. What do they want to know? do you need to tell them? Is it all there? Did you anticipate their questions? Did you lead them to pertinent related materials? Understand your audience’s connectivity limitations. Many users are accessing your webpages through ERAP with slow connection This fact should always be a big part of your decision of what to put your webpages. Use words and terminology appropriate to your intended audience. What words would your audience use? Clearly explain all new or non

standard terms. When you introduce or unfamiliar acronyms, use the acronym and then, in parentheses, out the name or expression. Do not assume that the audience is with the term from another page of content.

) Clearly state the purpose of the page in the ﬁrst paragraph. Introduce your topic at the start of your page and progress logically to the conclusion. Following this approach will help users identify if they are on the correct page. It can also help the search engine ﬁnd the correct page, based upon the content. • What does the audience need to know about the subject? • What should the audience do after they read the page? Make sure the desired action is clearly stated and supported by the content. • Link users to related webpages and resources when appropriate. (

) Brevity is key. People are uncomfortable reading content on the computer screen. Seventy-nine percent of web readers scan. As a guideline, try to use about half the words you would use in print publishing. • Use the inverted pyramid style of writing; put the most important infor- mation at the top. • Intranet writing should be shorter than writing for hardcopy. Remove all unnecessary words. Documents intended for online reading should rarely be over
words long.

) Clearly state the purpose of the page in the ﬁrst paragraph. Introduce your topic at the start of your page and progress logically to the conclusion. Following this approach will help users identify if they are on the correct page. It can also help the search engine ﬁnd the correct page, based upon the content.

Use the inverted pyramid style of writing; put the most important infor- mation at the top. Intranet writing should be shorter than writing for hardcopy. Remove all unnecessary words. Documents intended for online reading should rarely be over
words long.
page

Large Business and International • Break up long pieces into short segments. Let your audience choose how much they want to read. • Use headers and sub-headers, so people can go right to the sections they want. Use standard HTML header tags to facilitate “scanning” via screen readers. • Layer information - write short introductory paragraphs that link to in-depth information. • Organize information logically for the intended audience. • Limit yourself to one main idea per paragraph.
) Spelling, grammar, punctuation, and invalid link errors signiﬁcantly detract (
) the professional nature of LB&I content. Review all content to make sure Proofread errors are avoided. (

) In addition to proper spelling, grammar, and punctuation, content should be written using the AP Style and the IRS Style Guide. The LB&I C&L Staff is available to assist and advise writers upon request.

) This subsection provides guidance on the standard design elements used (

) throughout the LB&I Source. Most of these design elements are applied Standard Design through the use of the global CSS applied to the IRS Source site collection. Elements These style choices are made by IRS C&L, and should not be circumvented. Using the built-in headings and styles from the Source platform should be used. This subsection provides guidance in the event an exception is granted by the LB&I webmaster, and content has to be manually styled. (
) Content managers and SMEs should not use coding practices to circumvent the IRS Source styles, as it is designed to provide the consistent required by IRM
Using the built-in styles means that all content across the Source platform will update when the global styles are updated IRS C&L. (

This subsection is reserved for later use. Subsections 5 through 7 will be used to provide technical details, and coordination with Servicewide policies and

) This subsection provides guidance on the standard design elements used throughout the LB&I Source. Most of these design elements are applied through the use of the global CSS applied to the IRS Source site collection. These style choices are made by IRS C&L, and should not be circumvented. Using the built-in headings and styles from the Source platform should always be used. This subsection provides guidance in the event an exception is granted by the LB&I webmaster, and content has to be manually styled. (
) Content managers and SMEs should not use coding practices to circumvent the IRS Source styles, as it is designed to provide the consistent appearance required by IRM
Using the built-in styles means that all content across the Source platform will update when the global styles are updated by IRS C&L. (
) These standards are provided so that content managers can conﬁrm their LB&I Source lists conform to the standards, and request assistance if they
These standards are provided so that content managers can conﬁrm their LB&I Source lists conform to the standards, and request assistance if they
Intranet Publishing Standards 11.51.2
encounter difficulty. Additionally, some of the standards cannot be invoked through the global styles, and this subsection provides guidance on ing these elements.
Due to the use of the IRS Source platform on Shar

oint, organizations within LB&I will no longer have “landing pages” or “homepages”. The only “landing” pages used will be to provide navigation across the LB&I Source, to content residing in the various lists. These “landing” pages will be maintained by the LB&I Web Team.

Large Business and International (
) The usage of any other colors or schemas must receive prior approval from the LB&I Webmaster, and will likely require coordination with the IRS Office. (
) The standard font, font color and size used for all basic text on the LB&I intranet is Arial,
or
pt (
em). Regular, unformatted text placed in the Source template pages is automatically displayed in Arial. (
) The “One IRS Design Standards” should be preferred. The following identify the various font families used: • Serif: Times New Roman • Sans-serif: Helvetica or Arial (
) These font families are built into the global IRS Source styles. (

) Page headings (not to be confused with the page title displayed in the blue at the top of the browser window when a page is opened) are extremely important features of each webpage. They should communicate at a the subject of the page. The proper use of headings is not only important visual display to users, but also ensures
-compliance, by allowing readers to identify the structure of the page, and “read” the content accordingly. (
) In order to properly use the headings, and ensure

-compliance, use standard HTML heading style tags to deﬁne section and sub-section titles. not use font style settings to format headings, or mimic their appearance. predeﬁned heading formats that may be used are: • The main page heading is applied through the [Title] ﬁeld of the content in the IRS Source platform. This is automatically applied to page, in large red font at the top of the page. Content titles and page headings should be short — normally no more than
words, and limited to
characters. • Page sub-headings and document headings should use the
<h
> style option. These headings can generally be longer than headers, but should still be kept short. • Section headings should use the Heading
<h
> style option. are used to separate content in a logical fashion, and group content based upon topic. • Sub-section headings should use the Heading
<h

> style option. These headings should be rarely used. Too much content on a page can clutter the page, and make ﬁnding information difficult. As result, content should be spread across several pages, in a logical structure, that takes advantage of the inherent nature of hyperlinks across webpages. For this reason, Heading
will typically not be (
) Bold: Boldface font should be used for emphasis of text. The use of bold should be limited, and entire sentences should not be bolded. Bold font is identiﬁed by using the <strong> tag.
Large Business and International Communications

Intranet Publishing Standards 11.51.2
Standards
page (

) Italics: Italics should only be used for quoted material. When long sections of text are quoted, they should be indented to identify a blockquote. Other than quotations, italics should not be used, as it can cause eyestrain, and detract from the readability of the text. (

) Underline: Underlined text should never be used on the intranet, as it is reserved for automatic (default) styling of textual hyperlinks. The improper of underlining can cause user confusion, and the mistaken appearance that broken hyperlinks exist on the page. (

) Highlighted Text: Highlighted text should never be used on the intranet, as it can cause signiﬁcant eyestrain for sighted users, and is ignored by most screen-reading technology. Additionally, highlighted text on a webpage will often not display as highlighted when printed on a black-and-white printer. Note: Highlighted text may be used by the LB&I Web Team to identify old and unclaimed content. Until the content owner can be identiﬁed, and action taken, highlighted information should be considered obsolete and relied upon. (
) Other Stylized Text: Other stylized text should be avoided, as most practices can cause eyestrain, and are often not
-compliant. Additionally, certain styles are reserved for speciﬁc use; such as red-colored text, which is used identifying required ﬁelds, input validation errors, and other system (
) General information pages should be short and to the point — no more than screens in height (as scrolling on an
x

resolution screen size). They should highlight current or important developments and provide links to other parts of the list topic. Content should be organized into additional pages, to reduce webpage “clutter”. (

) When content must be on the same page, long pages of text should be into appropriate sections using the appropriate heading types, with links provided at the top of the page. “Back to the top” links should be at appropriate intervals to assist in page navigation. (

) The page title from a browser perspective is distinguished by the page (content title), in that it appears in the title bar of the browser window (it is visually displayed in the content area of the webpage). The title also appears as the label in bookmarks to the page, as the page header when the page is printed, and in search results, lists, and statistics reports. A page title should properly reﬂect the page’s content, be concise, and meaningful to the audience. This may, or may not, be the same as the page heading. (

) The page title is contained within the <title> tag, which resides in the <head> tag of the webpage. This is automatically duplicated from the [Title] of the content, which also becomes the page heading (<h
>), and placed into the HTML code for the page. Manually changing the <title> is no longer in the IRS Source platform.

) Underline: Underlined text should never be used on the intranet, as it is reserved for automatic (default) styling of textual hyperlinks. The improper of underlining can cause user confusion, and the mistaken appearance that broken hyperlinks exist on the page. (

) Highlighted Text: Highlighted text should never be used on the intranet, as it can cause signiﬁcant eyestrain for sighted users, and is ignored by most screen-reading technology. Additionally, highlighted text on a webpage will often not display as highlighted when printed on a black-and-white printer.

Large Business and International (
) As a general rule, all LB&I intranet content should be in webpage format. intranet runs on the IRS Source platform on a Shar

oint server, which the server-side function of Active Server Pages. In the instance that ﬁle downloads must be used, the ﬁles will be stored in a document library, and ﬁles provided via a link on relevant content pages. This ensures that users provided contextual explanations of the documents, in line with the links to document download. (

) Every effort must be made to provide a webpage version of content as opposed to a ﬁle for download, to ensure a consistent user experience the intranet. This means SMEs and content owners must create a webpage, text version of Microsoft Office or Adobe PDF documents, unless there is a bonaﬁde reason for providing content in a downloadable form (e.g.; a document needed for sharing with a taxpayer, or a proforma worksheet for data-entry). (

) Documents should not be uploaded simply to avoid having to create a webpage. HTML webpage content is preferred for the following reasons: • Webpages more efficient and use less bandwidth. • Webpages provide a more consistent user experience. • Webpages are more accessible to users with assistive software or devices (Section
compliant). • Webpages are much more highly ranked for search results due to better SEO. • Documents are not parsed for content and are ranked much lower in search results. (

) The ultimate goal of the LB&I Source is to provide information to the user, efficiently and correctly as possible. Every effort should be made to facilitate the user’s consumption of the information, rather than ease of development publication. (
) The LB&I Web Team can provide further guidance on making webpages Section
compliant, beyond this IRM section. Files made available for download (when a webpage is not created for the content) should be sent to the Alternative Media Center for review, prior to publishing. (

) In general, do not publish PDF document directly to the web. PDF should only be published to the web, when there is a valid purpose; for example, ﬁllable PDF documents or ﬁles for printing and offline use. Please note that most PDF forms are official forms or publications of the IRS. In instances, do not publish copies of official publications; instead, link to the forms repository version from your webpage. To have official documents published, contact IRS Publishing Services. (

) Do not publish official memoranda and other documents with official signa- tures. Instead create a webpage, mimicking the memoranda or document. In place of the signature line, the following will be placed to identify that an signed document exists elsewhere: /s/ [Signing Official’s [MM/DD/YYYY] Name]

) Publishing documents with an official signature compromises the security of the signature. Content authors should provide the Microsoft Word (or other word processing program) format, that gives all of the same text as the document to the SME or content manager for publishing. This facilitates creating the webpage version of the document more quickly, using paste (

) Official memoranda signed by LB&I executives and management must be published by the LB&I Web Team on the LB&I News Center under “Other Messages”. Content managers and SMEs will link to this published as needed. Official ﬁeld guidance and directives are subject to SBREFA and E-FOIA regulations, and should be published externally on IRS.gov by the LB&I Web Team. (

) In general, do not publish any Microsoft Word (.doc, .docx) ﬁles to the There are limited circumstances where these types of ﬁles need to be to users in the original format. Examples of the Word document exceptions are: • a pro-forma workpaper • a document template for ﬁeld personnel • a ﬁllable form in MS Word format (

) MS Excel spreadsheets (.xls, .xlsx) should also not be published to the Spreadsheets that only provide information to users in a tabular format (e.g. charts, metrics, etc.) should always be made into a webpage. Care should taken when creating tables in webpages as they are difficult to make acces- sible (
-compliant). Examples of Excel ﬁle exceptions are: • A pro forma worksheet • A spreadsheet made available for computational purposes (

oint presentations (.ppt, .pptx, .pps, .ppsx) should be made into a webpage. However, Powe
oint ﬁles also have exceptions to rule of not being published. Examples of Powe
oint ﬁle exceptions are: • Templates to be used in their original Powe
oint format. (templates should not deviate from the standard LB&I Powe

Large Business and International Communications
Large Business and International (

) In general, if a ﬁle is designed to be made available to users for but viewing the ﬁle online is not necessary, or appropriate, the ﬁle should be provided in the compressed .zip format. This is most common with large ﬁles, such as those used by Computer Audit Specialists, where opening the ﬁle directly from the web could burden the servers. (

) The compressed .zip format should not be used to circumvent the to make a webpage version of an Office document. Content Publishers must analyze the contents of a compressed .zip ﬁle, to determine if any (or all) of the ﬁles should be made into a webpage (or webpages). (
) Files should not be embedded within one another (e.g.; a Word document, embedded Powe
oint presentations and Excel spreadsheets). This not only greatly increases the ﬁle size, it also circumvents the policy, and is not
compliant. Files of this type found will be deleted. (

) The hyperlink formatting (color & underline) used on the LB&I intranet, is the default for the current browser and version approved by IRS IT. This should not be altered, without written authorization from the LB&I Webmaster. (
) When ﬁles are published to the web, a description of the ﬁle type and size must be displayed to the right of the hyperlink, in parentheses, as shown below:

Apply the following formatting standards to ﬁle hyperlinks: • The ﬁle type and size should be surrounded by standard parentheses. • Do NOT include the parenthetical as part of the hyperlinked text. • The ﬁle extension is provided in lowercase format, without the period character (“.”, e.g.: “doc”, “pdf”, etc.) • A space character should separate the ﬁle type from the ﬁle size. • There is no space between the numerical characters of the ﬁle size the letters indicating the ﬁle size measurement (e.g.: “
KB”, “

GB”) The letter characters used for ﬁle type and size designations of hyperlinked ﬁles should match the standard convention for ﬁle systems: • Only uppercase characters are used for the ﬁle size. Lowercase ters represent different values that aren’t used on the web. Example: “KB” = kilobytes, whereas “Kb” or “kb” = kilobits. There are bits in a byte. • Numerical values should be abbreviated for quick reading: Example:

Intranet Publishing Standards 11.51.2

Use photos, images, and graphics sparingly. Use of graphics will hinder or prevent a webpage from loading for ﬁeld personnel using a slower internet connection to access the LB&I intranet. Approximately
% of LB&I revenue agents still access the intranet site through aircards in the ﬁeld. The following table shows the typical download speeds for different types of con- nections:

included on a page. (
) The three primary image formats used for the web are: • .GIF (Graphic Interchange Format) • .JPG (Joint Photographic Experts Group) • .PNG (Portable Network Graphics) (

) Any images or graphics that are created in another format (e.g., .TIF, .BMP, and .SVG) must be converted to either .GIF , .JPG, or .PNG prior to on a webpage. Note that when you convert an image or graphic, certain aspects such as color or fonts may be affected, depending upon the format that it is converted to. Contact the LB&I Web Team for assistance in images to an appropriate format, without loss of color or resolution. (
) Reduce large image ﬁles to a “webpage” or “screen” resolution (or “print” lution as needed) before publishing on the web. The Microsoft Office Picture Manager program is suitable for this task. (
) Graphics Interchange Format (.GIF) If you are offered different “save” options for the .GIF format; save the graphics as “
a Non-Interlaced .GIF ﬁles”. Animated .GIF ﬁles will NOT be used on the LB&I intranet. (
) Joint Photographic Experts Group (.JPG) If you are offered compression options for the .JPG format, experiment with different compression levels to

) All non-text items, including images, must include an alternative text (’alt attribute. Most images should receive descriptive text regarding the image content. See IRM
, Accessibility of Web Content, for more tion. (
) Minimize any extraneous background space in an image by cropping it. will help focus attention on the subject of the photo and reduce the overall and Editing of the image. (

) No other editing should be done to images, including graphics and logos, the LB&I intranet. This includes photoshop editing and “touching up” of Only the IRS Design Office, Visual Information Specialists, and the LB&I Team have the authority to edit images on the web in this manner. (

) IRS Media & Publishing Services has introduced updated Design Standards the behest of the IRS Commissioner to help guide divisions and Branding in the proper development of formal documents, publications, presentations and similar materials. The Standards set forth include rules for correct use official IRS logos, seals, graphic designs and color schemes in IRS and publications. (

) The Design Standards are intended to reinforce the concept of “One IRS” ensuring the IRS brand appears properly and consistently across all parts the Service. LB&I has adopted these Standards and developed visuals to ensure that its own brand identity meets Servicewide requirements. (
) Refer to IRM
, Publishing, Use of the Official IRS Seal, IRS Logo, Program Logos and Internal Logos, and Document
, One look. One voice. One IRS., for more details and examples of how IRS Design are applied. (

) The IRS seal and Department of Treasury seal are used to represent the and Treasury in certain formal communications. In general, seals are used Seals on IRS letterhead stationary, official communications to the public from the Office of the Commissioner, other official and ceremonial documents and materials, and building signage. (

) The IRS and Treasury seals are not interchangeable with the IRS logo because they have historical signiﬁcance and are not easily distinguishable from other federal agency seals. Seals must be used in accordance with
, Official IRS Seal. (

) The official IRS logo is a graphic image consisting of the IRS eagle placed above or to the left of the acronym “IRS”. The IRS Logo must appear on all published and electronic products, with the exception of internal forms, and IRS letterhead. The IRS logo may be scaled to suit the needs of applications, but may not be modiﬁed or changed in any other manner, when applied using the IRS “Wayﬁnding” system.
11.51 Large Business and International Communications

No other editing should be done to images, including graphics and logos, on the LB&I intranet. This includes photoshop editing and “touching up” of images. Only the IRS Design Office, Visual Information Specialists, and the LB&I Web Team have the authority to edit images on the web in this manner.

) The IRS logo color may be black or IRS Blue on white, or White on IRS The IRS logo should always appear separate from any other images or elements of a page. No other content should touch or otherwise cover any of the IRS logo. (

Black logos and blue logos must appear on white background. White logos may appear on IRS Blue background. (
) Contact LB&I Communications & Liaison Office with questions about use of the IRS logo. (

) Many IRS divisions and departments are using homegrown logos and images to “brand” themselves visually. Because these logos and images inconsistent from one division and department to another, the overall IRS Wayﬁnding brand is weakened, possibly appearing disjointed and confusing to IRS taxpayers, employees and stakeholders. (

) To promote consistent branding and visual identity across the Service, Publishing Services has created a visual organizing framework called the ﬁnding” system. This system offers IRS offices a consistent, effective identifying and distinguishing themselves, ending the need for homegrown logos. (

) The wayﬁnding system incorporates names of operating divisions and ments in conjunction with the IRS logo. It reinforces the One IRS concept, while at the same time clearly identifying where various communications originate. (

) The wayﬁnding system also assigns standardized color palettes to IRS operating divisions and departments. Together with the department name, these assigned colors can help identify the source of published materials. Document
-U, IRS Design Standards One Sheet Booklet, for of how wayﬁnding logos and colors may be used in IRS publications and documents. (
) LB&I is fully embracing the IRS wayﬁnding system. The LB&I wayﬁnding may appear as blue-on-white, black-on-white, and white-on-blue. (

) LB&I organizations and departments are being asked to stop using System “homegrown” department logos and graphics and transition to the system. LB&I department-speciﬁc wayﬁnding graphics can be requested the LB&I Web Team. (

) This subsection provides guidance to ensure that content on the LB&I meets all applicable laws, including accessibility, privacy, and copyright. With Laws Content found to be non-compliant will be removed by the LB&I Web (

) All federal agencies are required by law to make their websites accessible people with disabilities. Content providers are responsible for ensuring that content they submit for publishing is compliant with the accessibility of Section
) Internal Revenue Manual
Intranet Publishing Standards 11.51.2
Large Business and International (
) LB&I Source standard templates have been designed to ensure that all accessibility requirements are met. Do not alter these templates; doing so alter their accessibility. (
) Additional resources for accessibility can be found at: • Information Resources Accessibility Program website • Alternative Media Center website (

) LB&I is committed to protecting the privacy of our employees in both and paper records. Due to the IRS Source platform, now every webpage on the site collection has a link to the Intranet Privacy Policy. LB&I program sites should not create their own privacy policy page. (

) Employees may not publish to an IRS intranet site any copyrighted material without license or written permission of the copyright owner. If there is any reason to believe that text, images, or other materials may belong to else, do not copy or otherwise use it without ﬁrst obtaining written (

) If permission to use copyrighted material has been obtained, its use on the LB&I Source is still subject to approval by the LB&I Webmaster and C&L Director. A copy of the written authorization to use the copyrighted material be required for C&L approval. For additional information about this policy, to IRM

) Graphics used on the LB&I Intranet site should be in the public domain. If an organization purchases graphics for the website, and the purchase speciﬁes that the vendor retains the copyright, then that fact should be noted on the page and in the text box (alt tag). A copy of the purchase agreement must be provided to the LB&I Webmaster for record retention. Any graphics purchased by organizations are the property of the IRS as an organization, and any licensing or purchase agreement must reﬂect this. (

) If an organization publishes written materials reprinted from outside sources, the content owner must have written authorization from the holder of the copyright to publish the materials on IRS’s website and the copyright must noted on each page of the material. A copy of the written authorization must provided to the LB&I Webmaster for record retention. (

) The requirement for written authorization does not include content that is in public domain, or falling under the Fair Use Doctrine; however, content managers are responsible for ensuring content used without written legally falls within these bounds. (
) Photos and graphics developed by grantees or contractors for IRS become property of the IRS and, therefore, are in the public domain. (

) Photos of employees and other individuals may be published to the web, with the individual’s written consent. Content managers and subject matter experts must retain a copy of the consent, as long as the photo is published their list (whether available through a webpage, or simply stored on the server).

page (
) Official forms are published in the Electronic Publishing Catalog. Do not lish copies of official documents that are available in the Electronic Catalog; link to them instead. (

) The Electronic Publishing Catalog Help Section provides instructions on properly linking to published products. Additional resources can be found at: • Electronic Publishing Catalog Help Page • Media and Publications Publishing IRM

) Surveys can be a valuable tool for collecting information in order to improve processes. However, care should be taken to ensure that certain things are avoided when using surveys. • Before requesting responses to a survey, ensure that all union ments are met. • Check that the survey, or portions of it, has not already been in some manner recently. • Do not request survey response during the same period as the Employee Satisfaction Survey. (

) In light of the above, the Program Planning Coordination & Analysis (PPCA) office of Technology and Program Solutions (TPS) has the responsibility for survey administration. All surveys should be coordinated through the PPCA office to ensure compliance with the Commissioner’s memoranda. (

) The LB&I C&L office and the LB&I Webmaster have the sole authority over LB&I Source architecture, navigation, and site pages (aka “landing pages”). and These are used to assist users of the site in locating content, and must conform to the same principles as the root of the site collection; the IRS Source. (
) News articles on the IRS Source homepage, such as the “News from the Business Units” (BUN) section, must be routed through the LB&I C&L office editing and approval. (
) Once root-level or IRS Source content is approved by the LB&I C&L office, communications analysts will coordinate with the requestor to provide the mation to the LB&I Web Team for publishing. (
) The LB&I Web Team will continually evaluate the content in the LB&I and make changes to the navigation as appropriate to aid users in ﬁnding content. (
) A decision tree for where content should be curated can be found in Exhibit
This decision tree is a guide, designed speciﬁcally for LB&I, ing the Servicewide Intranet Content Types presentation from

The Servicewide presentation was created to explain the change in content phy, and was not meant to be authoritative. The LB&I decision tree was created in this spirit, and in an attempt to provide more speciﬁc examples LB&I content.
